oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Roy Acuff and Wesley Rose Interview by Chet Hagan in 1980
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is an interview of Roy Acuff and Wesley Rose by Chet Hagan. The recording takes place on November 14th, 1980.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Roy Acuff; Wesley Rose;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:01) -- Chet Hagan introduction. (0:14) -- Chet Hagan mentions that he would like to ask Roy Acuff about the Dr. Hauer's Medicine Show days. (0:32) -- Chet Hagan asks about the Dr. Hauer's Medicine Show performances. (1:50) -- Roy Acuff mentions that they would start the show for crowds with fiddle, then go into a song. (3:22) -- Roy Acuff remembers material performed on the medicine show such as "Get Along Home Cindy." (3:48) -- Chet Hagan asks about Jake Tindall, Roy Acuff's comedic co-performer on Dr. Hauer's Medicine Show. Roy Acuff mentions that he took Jake Tindall's material to the Grand Ole Opry. (4:50) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff about the type of medicine sold by Dr. Hauer. Roy Acuff clarifies that the 'medicine' sold was named Moc-coton. (6:35) -- Roy Acuff discusses Dr. Hauer's "corn remedy." (7:06) -- Roy Acuff discusses the stage setup of Dr. Hauer's Medicine Show. The stage would be tall enough so children could not climb on. (7:40) -- Roy Acuff mentions that Dr. Hauer's Medicine Show would setup in a town for ten days to perform every night. (8:35) -- Roy Acuff mentions the name of the plays performed during the Medicine Show, such as "Over The River, Charlie," "Goin' Upstairs." (8:52) -- Roy Acuff clarifies that the plays would often run for thirty minutes. (10:15) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff whether Dr. Hauer's Medicine Show was his first professional job. Roy Acuff goes on to describe his interest in sports (baseball, basketball, football). (12:18) -- Roy Acuff describes his high-school play experience. (12:44) -- Roy Acuff describes his high-school sports experience (football, baseball). (13:37) -- Roy Acuff describes getting a sun stroke from playing baseball. (14:58) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff whether he tried out for professional baseball. (15:48) -- Roy Acuff describes his friends in professional baseball. (16:38) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff whether the sun stroke was an omen to start working in the show business. (17:16) -- Roy Acuff mentions that he liked to fight (box) when he was younger. (19:24) -- Roy Acuff mentions that he used to get into conflicts with the Knoxville Police. (20:11) -- Roy Acuff mentions that he's been shot before. (20:53) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff about when he first came to the Grand Ole Opry. (22:17) -- Roy Acuff describes singing "Great Speckled Bird." (23:14) -- Roy Acuff describes David Stone asking him to be a regular performer on the Grand Ole Opry. (24:08) -- Roy Acuff describes the reaction to his performance through radio. (24:45) -- Roy Acuff describes learning from his sister to sing from his chest. (25:19) -- Roy Acuff mentions that he used to sing on Knoxville Radio imitating Bing Crosby before developing his vocal style. (27:17) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff about whether he brought a band from Knoxville when coming to the Grand Ole Opry. Roy Acuff goes on to describe his personnel at the time. (28:42) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff about the future of The Grand Ole Opry. (30:08) -- Roy Acuff mentions his fondness for Red Foley and Tennessee Ernie. (31:15) -- Roy Acuff speaks on the effect of Uncle Dave Macon's passing on the Grand Ole Opry (1952). (31:37) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff what he thinks of himself as. (32:54) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff about the Japanese soldier story. (34:04) -- Roy Acuff discusses visiting Ernie Pyle's grave in Hawaii. Roy Acuff mentions that Ernie Pyle requested the tune "Great Speckled Bird" to be played at his funeral. (34:39) -- Roy Acuff mentions sending records to American soldiers during WWII onboard ships and in foxholes. (37:57) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff when he first started performing overseas. (39:24) -- Roy Acuff speaks on his touring habits. (40:16) -- Chet Hagan asks whether Roy Acuff performed with Minnie Pearl (tent show). (40:30) -- Roy Acuff clarifies that the tent show was not The Grand Ole Opry. (41:26) -- Roy Acuff describes a situation in Panama where he was shot at. (42:58) -- Chet Hagan asks Roy Acuff whether he felt frightened in Korea or Vietnam. (44:24) -- Roy Acuff describes going into the trenches at Korea.
